Award.AwardTitle: REU SITE: Research in Consumer Networking Technologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This funding renews a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Missouri - Columbia. Undergraduate students will engage in summer research involving a variety of interesting problems involving consumer networking technologies. The students will participate in the faculty mentors' on-going funded research, investigate technically challenging issues, and develop viable solutions and insights. They will participate in professional development activities to prepare them for future graduate studies and a broad range of emerging computing careers. The site will focus on recruiting students from non-PhD granting institutions with particular emphasis on institutions in and around the state of Missouri. The approach of integrating future technologies such as Internet-of-Things, smart devices, and software-defined networking in the REU Site research will foster the rapid deployment of advanced consumer networking applications and services that are of significance to the economy and quality of life in areas such as social computing, health care, and public safety.

The intellectual merit of the project rests with the leadership an experienced research group with excellent expertise and experience in the research area. Experienced faculty mentors will lead projects in four major research areas including software defined networking, visual computing at the network edge, social health networking, and body-area sensing and emotion recognition. The research activities will lead to a better understanding of the multitude of efficiency, performance, reliability, scalability, and security issues and tradeoffs in emerging consumer applications and related networking technologies. Advanced networking environments and software developed in the previous REU site programs as well as new testbeds such as the Missouri University Science DMZ (demilitarized zone), NSF-supported CloudLab/GENI, smart device equipment, and perfSONAR multi-domain networking monitoring will be leveraged by the participating students in hands-on experiments within their research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) Site at the University of Missouri was in the field of Consumer Networking Technologies and investigates important issues related to software defined networking, visual computing at the network edge, social health networking for eldercare, body-area sensing and emotion recognition. 30 REU students were selected from 224 applications received over the 3-year project period. The REU students worked in world-class collaborative research environments that fostered their enthusiasm for science and engineering, and helped them to develop research and communication skills needed for pursuing advanced degrees. The REU students participated in two field trips, one offered the opportunity to visit and speak with students in grades 6-­8 in the Columbia Public School district’s EEE summer school program; the other was a visit to the University of Missouri’s Data Center. At the end of the program, several students expressed their desire to pursue graduate study. Several graduate assistants were provided the opportunity to mentor undergraduate researchers, which will also significantly benefit their career development. REU students have disseminated their research results on a variety of consumer applications and networking research topics in poster presentations at MU and externally. They disseminated their results in IEEE/ACM conference/workshop sessions at CCNC, ICNC, NCA, BIBM, CUR, REUNS, and ICCE.
